cards.title: The Guardian film show / San Andreas, The Goob, Timbuktu

item.title: The Guardian film show: San Andreas, The Goob, Timbuktu – video reviews
item.trailText: In this week's show, Xan Brooks is joined by Peter Bradshaw and Catherine Shoard to review the big releases
item.standFirst: In this week's show, Xan Brooks is joined by Peter Bradshaw and Catherine Shoard to review the big releases, including 3D disaster movie San Andreas, starring Dwayne (The Rock) Johnson as a helicopter pilot who must rescue his wife and daughter from a pulverising San Francisco, The Goob, a coming-of-age tale set in East Anglia from first-time director Guy Myhill and Timbuktu, Abderrahmane Sissako's controversial drama about jihadis in an African village. They also answer some of your questions, which you can post in the comments below
item.byline: Xan Brooks, Peter Bradshaw, Catherine Shoard, Joan Portillo, Caterina Monzani and Dan Susman

cards.title: Brazilian man transforms home into his dream skatepark
cards.rawTitle: Brazilian man transforms home into his dream skatepark

item.title: Brazilian man transforms entire home into his dream skatepark
item.trailText: Anselmo Arruda has made his home, in Itanhaem, Sao Paulo state, into a skate park
item.standFirst: Anselmo Arruda has made his home in Itanhaem, Sao Paulo, into a skate park. Because he lived alone, he had more room than he knew what to do with, he says. So he started moving out furniture to make room to skate. Before long, sinks were pulled out and he started building quarter-pipes up the sides of remaining walls. Today the 'cave house' welcomes people from all over Sao Paulo. Arruda says the sport helped save his life, and he hopes the house will help others overcome hardship too

stillImage.caption: Brazilian man, Anselmo Arruda, has made his home into a skateboarder's dream house by completely gutting it and converting it into a full-fledged skate park. ITANHAEM, SAO PAULO STATE. 29 May 2015 Photograph: Reuters Photograph: Reuters
stillImage.cleanCaption: Brazilian man, Anselmo Arruda, has made his home into a skateboarder's dream house by completely gutting it and converting it into a full-fledged skate park. ITANHAEM, SAO PAULO STATE. 29 May 2015 Photograph: Reuters

displayImages.caption: Brazilian man, Anselmo Arruda, has made his home into a skateboarder's dream house by completely gutting it and converting it into a full-fledged skate park. ITANHAEM, SAO PAULO STATE. 29 May 2015 Photograph: Reuters Photograph: Reuters

displayImages.cleanCaption: Brazilian man, Anselmo Arruda, has made his home into a skateboarder's dream house by completely gutting it and converting it into a full-fledged skate park. ITANHAEM, SAO PAULO STATE. 29 May 2015 Photograph: Reuters

cards.title: Around Lake Chad / Boko Haram's legacy of ruin and fear
cards.rawTitle: Boko Haram's legacy of ruin and fear

item.title: Around Lake Chad: Boko Haram's legacy of ruin and fear
item.trailText: The sun-scorched land around Lake Chad has become home to thousands of people who have fled attacks by Boko Haram militants in neighbouring Nigeria. But the militants have also attacked islands in the lake. Photographer Tomaso Clavarino visited the area and found burnt-out homes, shut-up shops, piles of ashes and a lingering sense of fear
item.standFirst: The sun-scorched land around Lake Chad has become home to thousands of people who have fled attacks by Boko Haram militants in neighbouring Nigeria. But the militants have also attacked islands in the lake. Photographer Tomaso Clavarino visited the area and found burnt-out homes, shut-up shops, piles of ashes and a lingering sense of fear

displayImages.caption:
Near the village of Forkouloum, on the banks of Lake Chad, refugees have cobbled together a makeshift shelter. Thousands of people have crossed into this harsh land, fleeing attacks by Boko Haram militants in neighbouring north-east Nigeria

All photographs by Tomaso Clavarino
displayImages.altText: Near the village of Forkouloum, on the banks of Lake Chad, refugees have cobbled together a makeshift shelter.
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Near the village of Forkouloum, on the banks of Lake Chad, refugees have cobbled together a makeshift shelter. Thousands of people have crossed into this harsh land, fleeing attacks by Boko Haram militants in neighbouring north-east Nigeria

All photographs by Tomaso Clavarino

displayImages.caption: Nigerian refugees play football at the Dar es Salaam refugee camp, near Bagasola, a village on the banks of Lake Chad. The camp was set up by the UN refugee agency UNHCR. Around 5,000 people, including many children without parents, are living here. ‘People who arrive here are facing enormous difficulties,’ said Alexandre Izart, of Médecins sans Frontières. ‘On the one hand, the conditions of the camp, at the very edge of survival; on the other, the trauma, often impossible to forget’
displayImages.altText: Young Nigerian refugees playing football in the Dar es Salaam camp.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Nigerian refugees play football at the Dar es Salaam refugee camp, near Bagasola, a village on the banks of Lake Chad. The camp was set up by the UN refugee agency UNHCR. Around 5,000 people, including many children without parents, are living here. ‘People who arrive here are facing enormous difficulties,’ said Alexandre Izart, of Médecins sans Frontières. ‘On the one hand, the conditions of the camp, at the very edge of survival; on the other, the trauma, often impossible to forget’

displayImages.caption: Burnt-out homes in Ngouboua village, on one of the small islands in Lake Chad. The village was attacked by around 40 Boko Haram fighters on 13 February. Houses were destroyed, cars burnt. Fear still hangs in the ash-heavy air
displayImages.altText: Burnt-out homes in Ngouboua village on one of the small islands in Lake Chad.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Burnt-out homes in Ngouboua village, on one of the small islands in Lake Chad. The village was attacked by around 40 Boko Haram fighters on 13 February. Houses were destroyed, cars burnt. Fear still hangs in the ash-heavy air

displayImages.caption: Nearly two-thirds of the houses in Ngouboua have been destroyed. Shops are closed, and the market is deserted. Boko Haram’s six-year insurgency in north-east Nigeria has left at least 15,000 dead and 1.5 million people homeless
displayImages.altText: Nearly two-thirds of the houses in Ngouboua were destroyed.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Nearly two-thirds of the houses in Ngouboua have been destroyed. Shops are closed, and the market is deserted. Boko Haram’s six-year insurgency in north-east Nigeria has left at least 15,000 dead and 1.5 million people homeless

displayImages.caption: A man in Ngouboua, seen through the window of the police station. ‘The attack ... was the first on the territory of Chad and many others followed,’ said Amdallah Mallaye, the chief of police. ‘The population lives in fear’
displayImages.altText: A man in Ngouboua seen from inside the police station.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A man in Ngouboua, seen through the window of the police station. ‘The attack ... was the first on the territory of Chad and many others followed,’ said Amdallah Mallaye, the chief of police. ‘The population lives in fear’

displayImages.caption: Burnt homes in Ngouboua. Some of those who fled the February attack had come here previously from Nigeria. In March, Boko Haram pledged allegiance to Islamic State. It is seeking to create a caliphate in north-east Nigeria
displayImages.altText: Burnt homes in Ngouboua.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Burnt homes in Ngouboua. Some of those who fled the February attack had come here previously from Nigeria. In March, Boko Haram pledged allegiance to Islamic State. It is seeking to create a caliphate in north-east Nigeria

displayImages.caption: A Chadian soldier patrols Ngouboua. Chad, Niger and Cameroon launched a series of offensives with Nigeria this year and have recaptured much of the territory occupied by Boko Haram. Nigerian troops are trying to tease the militants out of their strongholds in Nigeria’s Borno state, which borders Lake Chad
displayImages.altText: Chadian soldier patrolling Ngouboua.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A Chadian soldier patrols Ngouboua. Chad, Niger and Cameroon launched a series of offensives with Nigeria this year and have recaptured much of the territory occupied by Boko Haram. Nigerian troops are trying to tease the militants out of their strongholds in Nigeria’s Borno state, which borders Lake Chad

displayImages.caption: Chadian soldiers during a patrol near Bagasola. The soldiers have also been hunting militants on the lake’s islands, but the surrounding swampland makes the operation very difficult
displayImages.altText: Chadian soldiers during a patrol near Bagasola, a village on the banks of Lake Chad. The soldiers have also been hunting militants on the lake’s islands, but the surrounding swampland makes the operation very difficult.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Chadian soldiers during a patrol near Bagasola. The soldiers have also been hunting militants on the lake’s islands, but the surrounding swampland makes the operation very difficult

displayImages.caption: Young Boko Haram militants who surrendered to the Chadian army. Djibrine, a 12-year-old from eastern Chad, says he was captured with others when he went to study at a Koranic school in Borno. ‘They began putting horrible ideas into our heads, made promises of paradise that we would reach. They also gave us money. They forced us to kill, otherwise we would have been killed,’ he says. Djibrine and some others managed to escape and fled to Chad
displayImages.altText: Young Boko Haram militants who surrendered to the Chadian army.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Young Boko Haram militants who surrendered to the Chadian army. Djibrine, a 12-year-old from eastern Chad, says he was captured with others when he went to study at a Koranic school in Borno. ‘They began putting horrible ideas into our heads, made promises of paradise that we would reach. They also gave us money. They forced us to kill, otherwise we would have been killed,’ he says. Djibrine and some others managed to escape and fled to Chad

displayImages.caption: Chadian soldiers near Tchoukou Telia, a village where seven people were killed in an ambush by Boko Haram a few weeks ago
displayImages.altText: Chadian soldiers near Tchoukou Telia, a village where seven people were killed in an ambush by Boko Haram a few weeks ago.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Chadian soldiers near Tchoukou Telia, a village where seven people were killed in an ambush by Boko Haram a few weeks ago

displayImages.caption: A Nigerian refugee at the Dar es Salaam camp. ‘It is very difficult to have reliable numbers of the refugees and displaced people who have arrived here in the past few months because some of them are just passing through and others prefer to go back to Nigeria after a few weeks, given the harsh living conditions,’ said MSF’s Izart. He estimates there are around 16,000 refugees or displaced people in the area
displayImages.altText: A Nigerian refugee at the Dar es Salaam camp. ‘It is very difficult to have reliable numbers of the refugees and displaced people who have arrived here in the past few months,’ said MSF’s Izart, ‘because some of them are just passing through and others prefer to go back to Nigeria after a few weeks, given the harsh living conditions.’ He estimates that there were around 16,000 refugees or displaced people in the area.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A Nigerian refugee at the Dar es Salaam camp. ‘It is very difficult to have reliable numbers of the refugees and displaced people who have arrived here in the past few months because some of them are just passing through and others prefer to go back to Nigeria after a few weeks, given the harsh living conditions,’ said MSF’s Izart. He estimates there are around 16,000 refugees or displaced people in the area

displayImages.caption: Youngsters silhouetted on the road between Baga Sola and Dar es Salaam camp, which can only host people who have fled across borders. Others, like those who have left the islands, try to find refuge with local communities. ‘They are hosted by families who already have little or nothing to survive on,’ says Alice Sequi, head of the UN’s Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (Ocha) in the Chadian capital N’Djamena
displayImages.altText: Youngsters silhouetted on the road between Bagasola and Dar es Salaam camp.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Youngsters silhouetted on the road between Baga Sola and Dar es Salaam camp, which can only host people who have fled across borders. Others, like those who have left the islands, try to find refuge with local communities. ‘They are hosted by families who already have little or nothing to survive on,’ says Alice Sequi, head of the UN’s Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (Ocha) in the Chadian capital N’Djamena

displayImages.caption: A man in Baga Sola. The surrounding area has been hit hard by the closure of the border with Nigeria. Business activities have been shut down for months
displayImages.altText: A man in Baga Sola. The surrounding area has been hit hard by the closure of the border with Nigeria. Business activities have been shut down for months, and fishing boats are beached as their owners are too frightened to head out onto the lake.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A man in Baga Sola. The surrounding area has been hit hard by the closure of the border with Nigeria. Business activities have been shut down for months

displayImages.caption: A young refugee in Baga Sola hospital. Sequi, of Ocha, says getting aid into this remote area is difficult. ‘The crisis, because this is what it actually is, is not receiving the necessary support from donors, and from the international community. We did not even collect a third of the amount we believed to be essential’
displayImages.altText: A young refugee in Baga Sola hospital.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A young refugee in Baga Sola hospital. Sequi, of Ocha, says getting aid into this remote area is difficult. ‘The crisis, because this is what it actually is, is not receiving the necessary support from donors, and from the international community. We did not even collect a third of the amount we believed to be essential’

displayImages.caption: A man from northern Nigeria at Baga Sola hospital
displayImages.altText: A man from northern Nigeria at Baga Sola hospital.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A man from northern Nigeria at Baga Sola hospital

displayImages.caption: Because the border is closed, fuel prices have rocketed. ‘The economy is blocked,’ says Mbaihomadji Waibo Job, commander of the gendarmerie in Baga Sola. ‘Food prices have increased by 80% over the past few weeks; gasoline prices have reached unprecedented highs’
displayImages.altText: Because the border is closed, fuel prices have rocketed.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Because the border is closed, fuel prices have rocketed. ‘The economy is blocked,’ says Mbaihomadji Waibo Job, commander of the gendarmerie in Baga Sola. ‘Food prices have increased by 80% over the past few weeks; gasoline prices have reached unprecedented highs’

displayImages.caption: Rubbish clogging the banks of Lake Chad, near Ngouboua
displayImages.altText: Rubbish clogging the banks of Lake Chad, Africa's fourth largest lake by surface area.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Rubbish clogging the banks of Lake Chad, near Ngouboua

displayImages.caption: In the last 50 years, Lake Chad has shrunk to nearly a 20th of its original size, due both to climatic changes and to high demands for agricultural water
displayImages.altText: Those who have fled here seeking refuge from violence find little comfort from the landscape. Since 1963 Lake Chad has shrunk to nearly a twentieth of its original size due to climatic changes and high demands for agricultural water.
displayImages.cleanCaption: In the last 50 years, Lake Chad has shrunk to nearly a 20th of its original size, due both to climatic changes and to high demands for agricultural water

cards.title: Mediterranean / Royal Navy rescues hundreds of migrants from stricken ship
cards.rawTitle: Royal Navy rescues hundreds of migrants from stricken ship

item.title: Royal Navy rescues hundreds of migrants from stricken ship in Mediterranean
item.trailText: The Royal Navy's HMS Bulwark rescues 369 migrants from an overcrowded wooden-hulled boat in the waters just north of Libya
item.standFirst: The Royal Navy's HMS Bulwark rescues 369 migrants crammed into an overcrowded wooden-hulled boat which was in the waters just north of Libya. The ship sent five of its landing craft to rescue the migrants – 50 of whom were small children – from their unstable 'double-decker' craft

stillImage.caption: The Royal Navy rescue migrants from a striken boat in the Mediterranean. 29 May 2015 Photograph: Reuterso Photograph: Reuterso
stillImage.cleanCaption: The Royal Navy rescue migrants from a striken boat in the Mediterranean. 29 May 2015 Photograph: Reuterso

cards.title: Fifa in crisis / How the world's newspapers reacted

item.title: Fifa in crisis: how the world's newspapers reacted – in pictures
item.trailText: Following the news that nine Fifa officials and four executives of sports management companies had been arrested on suspicion of receiving bribes totalling $100m (£65m), football’s governing body featured on front pages around the world

item.title: Photo highlights of the day: Fifa raids and a wolf in sheep's clothing
